div.p: >> Hi, this is Joyce Farrell.

I want to talk to you about
understanding computer files.

When you store data in a
computer, you have two choices.

Temporary volatile memory,
also called RAM, which stands
for random access memory.

This is where you store
data that the program

that you're using
currently is working with.

You also can store data in
permanent, nonvolatile storage

for longer periods
of time, maybe days
or weeks between using it.
Hardware devices that are used

for nonvolatile storage include
hard disks, DVDs, USB drives,
and on larger systems,

frequently reels
of magnetic tape.

Every file that you store in
a computer system has a name.

And the name often ends with
a dot and an extension,

and the extension tells you
the type of file that it is.

For example, you might store a
document called TermPaper.doc.

And the .doc would indicate that
it's a word-processing document

that can be used by a
word-processing program.

Another file might be
called GraduationPhoto.jpg.

And jpg is an extension that
means it's a photograph file.

Employees.dat might
be a data file.

This might be a file that
holds the facts and figures

about your employees that could
be used by a personnel program

or a payroll program
in your organization.

Besides a name, every
file has a date and a time
that it was last modified.

And that information is
stored on your system.

And besides a name and a
time, every file has a size.

The size of computer
files is measured
in bits at the lowest level.

Bits are the little zeros and
ones that make up the circuitry
of the computer system.

Bits are so small that when
people talk about data,
they seldom refer to bits.
Instead, they refer to bytes.

It takes eight bits
to make a byte.

And typically, eight bits are
required to store a character,
such as an A or a B or a 7.

Bytes are so small that
when people talk about data,

they more frequently
talk about kilobytes.

A kilobyte is approximately
1,000 bytes.

So, a small file might be one
or two kilobytes in size.

Sometimes kilobytes are too
small to refer to large files,

so you might talk
about megabytes,
which are millions of bytes.

And computer memory itself is
often measured in gigabytes,
which are billions of bytes.

There are also additional
terms that refer
to larger quantities of storage.

When you store files
on a hardware device,

such as a hard drive, you might
organize the files into folders.

And within a folder, you might
have additional subfolders.
And within a subfolder,

you might have even more
additional subfolders.

The complete list of
the hardware device,

plus all the folders that lead
to the ultimate file location,
is called the file's path.

Let's take a look at
some typical files stored
on a computer.

For example, if you're using
the Vista operating system

and you open up the
computer icon,

you might see some
hardware devices
that are part of your computer.

This computer happens
to have an E drive,
an E Drive and a C drive.

If you open up the C
Ddrive by double-clicking,

you might see some folders
that are stored on that drive.

And I have one called
FileDemonstration.
If I open up FileDemonstration,

you can see that the
path is the C drive,
the FileDemonstration folder,

and then there are some
individual files stored there.

For example, I have one
called ShoppingList.

It has a date and time
that it was last modified.
And it's a text document.
And that means you can read it.

And it's one kilobyte in size,
approximately 1,000 bytes.

If you open up the
shopping list,

you can see that it's just
a short shopping list.

As a matter of fact,
it has far fewer
than 1,000 bytes stored in it.

If you right-click on ShoppingList
and choose its properties,

you can see the name of the
file and what program opens it.

And you can see that it
is only 35 bytes in size.

That's how many letters it took
to store the shopping list.

But when you look into my
computer, the smallest size

that is ever shown
is one kilobyte.

So, it's showing you the least
number it can show you for this.

I also have something
called TestDraw.
It's a CLASS file.

It happens to be
a program written

in the Java programming
language that has been compiled.

If you open up this file,
it's not very readable.

There's a few words in
there that you can identify,

but there's also a
lot of other codes.

These codes are in binary and
are readable to the computer,
but not very readable to you.

I happen to have a JPEG
file, which is 105 kilobytes,

much larger than any
of these other files.

Pictures take up
a lot of storage.

If you open that,
you see a picture.

The employee file
is a data file.

It's very typical of the kinds
of files you'll use as inputs
into computer programs.

For example, this one happens
to have employee ID numbers,

employees' last names,
first names, and pay rates.

And if you wrote a
computer program,

you might have a statement
such as input, ID number,
last name, first name, pay rate.

And it would use this
employee data file.

Let's take a little closer
look at the Employees data file

and talk for a minute
about the data hierarchy.

The smallest piece
of data that's useful
to humans is the character.

For example, the M
here in Mary Ann.

Characters are grouped
together to make up fields.

A field is a unit
of information,

such as a first name,
highlighted here.

Other fields in this data file
seem to be an employee number

and a last name and
a rate of pay.

Fields are grouped
together to make up records.

A record consists of all
the fields that have to do

with one entity, such as
a person, place, or thing.

And records are grouped
together to make up files.

A data file consists of all of
the records that go together
to solve some business problem.
Thanks for watching.
